Award.AwardTitle: Symposium: Building Bridges from Genome to Phenome: Molecules, Methods and Models, Austin, TX; January 3-7, 2020
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a symposium, "Building Bridges from Genome to Phenome: Molecules, Methods and Models," at the Annual Meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB) meeting in Austin, Texas, Jan. 3-7, 2020. The oral and poster presentations and related activities will cover a broad range of scientific efforts to understand how genes can shape species-specific characteristics while also giving rise to individual variation. Understanding the mechanistic basis by which genes give rise to both stability and variation in phenotypes is one of the Grand Challenges articulated by NSF. Scientists in many disciplines are taking a wide variety of approaches to dissect the mechanistic bases by which genes give rise to phenotypes, called genome-to-phenome studies. The goal of this Symposium will be to build connections among the most successful of these research efforts, as well as to identify key gaps and future needs to accelerate and facilitate this critical area of research. Activities of the Building Bridges Symposium are designed to encourage and support presentations and participation by established and new investigators, as well as postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate researchers representing diversity in gender and ethnicity, and with expertise in the wide range of disciplines represented within SICB. Taken together, the Symposium activities aim to facilitate rapid and insightful progress toward understanding the processes underlying constancy and variation, making it possible for species to be resilient in a changing world. Presentations from the Symposium, and a summary paper resulting from the Symposium and associated activities, will be widely disseminated via publication in the SICB journal.

The Symposium is organized by members of the NSF-supported Animal Genome-to-Phenome Research Coordination Network (AG2P RCN), which was established five years ago. The AG2P RCN's first symposium and policy workshop were conducted at the 2016 SICB Meeting. The white paper resulting from that workshop emphasized the need to standardize and lower the barriers for analysis of transcriptomic data, so that scientists from many disciplines and research environments could develop consensus approaches for the "taking-off point" for linking genomic with phenotypic diversity. Since 2016, there has been a huge proliferation of experimental organisms as well as of large and complex datasets describing various levels of biological organization, all aiming to elucidate aspects of the genome-to-phenome framework. The 2020 Building Bridges Symposium aims to identify and bridge gaps in this framework and the most promising future directions for genome-to-phenome research. In addition to oral and poster presentations, the Symposium includes an introductory session to initiate exchange of ideas and contact information, (2) a Twitter feed to gather comments from SICB members regarding major barriers to integrating data across disciplines, levels of organization and models, and (3) a policy workshop to outline a white paper identifying major gaps, key barriers and leading edges in the field of genome-to-phenome research. The Symposium and related activities will use an interdisciplinary collaborative model that will provide meaningful professional and scientific development opportunities as well as formal and informal opportunities for participants to network with each other across disciplines, gender, ethnicity, and professional ranks. All presentations in the Symposium will be published in the SICB journal and thereby will be widely disseminated and have abroader impact on the field.

This conference is being co-funded by the Integrative Ecological Physiology and Physiological Mechanisms and Biomechanics Programs within NSF-BIO-Integrative Organismal Biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from this award provided partial support for invited and contributed speakers, poster presenters, and workshops that comprised the Society-wide Symposium "Building Bridges from Genome to Phenome: Molecules, Methods and Models" held January 3-7, 2020, at the Annual Meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB) in Austin, TX. In addition to this award, the Symposium also received partial financial support from the NSF-supported Animal Genome to Phenome Research Coordination Network (AG2P RCN), as well as 7 of the disciplinary Divisions and 2  Societies affiliated with SICB.

Intellectual Merit: At its core, the Symposium program of invited speakers, with associated complementary oral and poster sessions, introductory lunch workshop and white paper workshop, delved into recent progress linking phenotype plasticity to changes at the level of the genome, epigenome, and proteome, while exploring the boundaries between variation and speciation. Presentations, discussions and syntheses focused on new approaches, models and methodological challenges in melding different types of datasets (genomic, transcriptomic, epigenetic, proteomic, metabolomic) to ask questions about linkages between the genome and phenome in non-model organisms. Research groups representing a wide range of disciplines presented research reports, status of the field summaries and conceptual models addressing the status of genome-to-phenome research at the present time (January 2020). In the introductory and follow-up workshops, participants were asked to identify areas of recent and notable progress, significant problems and research avenues that deserve particular emphasis in future funding initiatives. Workshop discussion groups generally recognized the absence of an overarching theoretical framework underlying current genome to phenome research at the present time and, therefore, called for a new emphasis on the development of conceptual models as well as the interdisciplinary collaborations needed to create and test those models. Participants also recognized a critical need for new and improved molecular and bioinformatic approaches to assist in describing function/phenotypes across phylogeny. And, like all scientific endeavors, progress in genome to phenome research would be enhanced by improvements in science education and communication both within and among working groups. Symposium presentations served as the basis for a published volume of manuscripts (2020, Integrative and Comparative Biology, Volume 60:2). The volume also included a White Paper that synthesized discussion from the workshops.

Broader Impacts: The Symposium was remarkably successful in promoting interdisciplinary interactions, discussions and consensus-building efforts.  Each of the invited and contributed posters and paper sessions, as well as the workshops, enjoyed participation from the wide of the disciplines represented within SICB, including the Divisions of Comparative Physiology and Biochemistry, Comparative Endocrinology, Evolutionary Developmental Biology, Ecoimmunology and Disease Ecology, Ecology and Evolution, Invertebrate Zoology, and Phylogenetics and Comparative Biology as well as the affiliated societies The Crustacean Society and American Microscopical Society. Each of the sessions also enjoyed broad participation and interaction among scientists across professional status, genders, and race. Lead authors for invited and contributing sessions included 3 undergraduate and 2 graduate students, 6 postdoctoral fellows, 5 assistant professors and 9 senior investigators.  Among the research leads, 38% were women. The presenter group also included 5 Hispanic, 1 Native American and 2 Asian American scientists. The workshops benefited from robust participation by conference attendees, including 30 at the lunch workshop and 42 at the White Paper workshop. Along with support from the AG2P-RCN and SICB-affiliated groups, funds from this award supported registration, travel, lodging and meals for 8 senior investigators, 3 junior investigators, 7 postdoctoral fellows, 3 graduate students and 2 undergraduate students who made presentations in the invited or complementary sessions of the Symposium.
